sourceDesc.bibl: Turnbull, Gavin,"Prologue." Columbian Herald and New Daily Advertiser (Charleston, SC), March 26, 1796

head.title: Elegy.11 Published in Columbian Herald and New Daily Advertiser [Charleston, SC] (March 31, 1796).

lg.l: No other maid of all the youthful tain,
However sweet to others she may be,
Shall e’er engage my constant heart again;

None can I, Myra,22 First used by seventeenth-century poet, Fulke Greville, Lord Brooke (1554-1628); see “Sonnet XXII,” in Cælica (c.1577). Cf. also David Mallet, “To Mira, from the Country,” in Miscellaneous Poems and Translations vol. 1 (1726), pp. 306-308, and Alexander Pope, Windsor Forest (1731), lines 290-296. ever love but thee.
From thee at first the fatal arrow came,
And to my heart an easy passage sound;
With secret joy I fed the pleasing flame,
Anscious of the anguish of my wound.
But alas, dear charmer! Little did I know
What racks, what torments, I was doom'd to prove
Disdain the fatal cause of all my woe,
And jealousy, the cause of constant love.
No friend of fortune I, no wealthy swain
Posses’d of num’rous herds and fields of corn;
For this I suffer you unjust disdain;
Not me, but 'tis poverty you scorn.
Say why, ye Gods! Should such a heav'nly form,
A virgin cast in Nature’s fairest mould,
The sordid vice of av’rice deform,
To barter truth and innocence for gold.
Yet, yet dear Maid, the little I could claim-
All that I could command or call it mine,
Though small my store, that little your’s became,
My heart, my life, my very soul was thine.
What task can you enjoin me to obey,
What dreadful penance urge me to sustain?
Be what it will, impatient of delay,
It shall be done, thy favor to obtain.
For thee I’ll brave the dangers of the storm;

Like young Leander33 In Greek mythology, Leander swam across the Hellespont every night to be with his lover, Hero. The myth was versified by Christopher Marlowe and, after Marlowe’s death, finished by George Chapman and published as Hero and Leander (1598). nightly swim the tide;
Undaunted meet its most terrific form,
If you appear my watry course to guide.
But, ah! Vain youth! What fury moves they mind-
What frantic rage constrains thee this
Already, to they sorrow may’st thou find,
She knows of thy submission far too well.
